rating_criteria.description: Headaches are rated based on frequency and severity of prostrating attacks and economic impact

levels.criteria: Characteristic prostrating attacks averaging one in 2 months over the last several months
Characteristic prostrating attacks occurring on an average once a month over the last several months
Very frequent completely prostrating and prolonged attacks productive of severe economic inadaptability

prostrating.va_definition: Causing extreme exhaustion, powerlessness, debilitation or incapacitation with substantial inability to engage in ordinary activities
examples: Must lie down in dark room

completely_prostrating.description: More severe than prostrating - total incapacitation during attack
completely_prostrating.note: Required for 50% rating along with prolonged duration

severe_economic_inadaptability.description: Headaches significantly impact ability to work and earn income
severe_economic_inadaptability.note: Does not require unemployment, but must show substantial work impact

headache_pain: Pain localized to one side of head
Pain on both sides of head
associated_symptoms: Changes in vision (scotoma, flashes, tunnel vision)
Sensory changes (pins and needles in extremities)

frequency.for_50_percent: Very frequent - more than once per month

tips_for_veterans: Keep a detailed headache diary documenting EVERY attack
Record date, time, duration, and severity of each headache
Document what you cannot do during an attack (this shows prostration)
Track missed work days and reduced productivity
Describe your WORST headaches, not just average ones
Mention ALL symptoms: nausea, light sensitivity, etc.
Document medications taken and their effectiveness
Explain how headaches affect your job and income
Get buddy statements from family/coworkers who witness attacks
Bring medication records showing continuous treatment
common_mistakes: Not documenting frequency of prostrating attacks
Failing to explain what 'prostrating' means for you
Forgetting to mention all associated symptoms
Not explaining how attacks affect daily activities

common_primaries.connection: Post-traumatic headaches are very common after TBI
Stress and anxiety can trigger and worsen migraines
Neck problems can cause cervicogenic headaches
Associated with headaches in some veterans
Sinus conditions can cause headache pain

important_notes: Prostrating = unable to perform ordinary activities during attack
50% rating requires BOTH very frequent attacks AND severe economic impact
Keep detailed records - frequency is KEY to rating
All headache types (migraine, tension, cluster) are rated under same criteria
Associated symptoms (nausea, light sensitivity) support migraine diagnosis
